<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 216, 304, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics 1 (M1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 195, 907, 210]]<|/det|>
9709/43  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 217, 907, 232]]<|/det|>
May/June 2011  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 238, 907, 253]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 322, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 352, 828, 368]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 330, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 495, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 462, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 493, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 590, 526]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 526, 606, 542]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 606, 572]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 756, 588]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 440, 604]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 605, 907, 635]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A block is pulled for a distance of \(50 \mathrm{~m}\) along a horizontal floor, by a rope that is inclined at an angle of \(\alpha^{\circ}\) to the floor. The tension in the rope is \(180 \mathrm{~N}\) and the work done by the tension is \(8200 \mathrm{~J}\). Find the value of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 152, 92, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 920, 216]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1250\mathrm{kg}\) is travelling along a straight horizontal road with its engine working at a constant rate of \(P\mathrm{W.}\) The resistance to the car's motion is constant and equal to \(R\mathrm{N}.\) When the speed of the car is \(19\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) its acceleration is \(0.6\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 2}\) , and when the speed of the car is \(30\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) its acceleration is \(0.16\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 2}\) . Find the values of \(P\) and \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 203, 920, 220]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 246, 96, 263]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 255, 717, 408]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected from the top of a smooth ramp with speed \(u \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) , and travels down a line of greatest slope. The ramp has length \(6.4 \mathrm{~m}\) and is inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. Another particle \(Q\) is released from rest at a point \(3.2 \mathrm{~m}\) vertically above the bottom of the ramp, at the same instant that \(P\) is projected (see diagram). Given that \(P\) and \(Q\) reach the bottom of the ramp simultaneously, find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 500, 153, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 500, 275, 518]]<|/det|>
the value of \(u\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 920, 518]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 524, 151, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 524, 603, 543]]<|/det|>
the speed with which \(P\) reaches the bottom of the ramp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 524, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 83, 895, 295]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 312, 920, 394]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the velocity-time graphs for the motion of two particles \(P\) and \(Q\), which travel in the same direction along a straight line. \(P\) and \(Q\) both start at the same point \(X\) on the line, but \(Q\) starts to move \(T\) s later than \(P\). Each particle moves with speed \(2.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) for the first \(20 \mathrm{~s}\) of its motion. The speed of each particle changes instantaneously to \(4 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) after it has been moving for \(20 \mathrm{~s}\) and the particle continues at this speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 408, 156, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 406, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
Make a rough copy of the diagram and shade the region whose area represents the displacement of \(P\) from \(X\) at the instant when \(Q\) starts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 425, 918, 442]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 628, 472]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(P\) has travelled \(70 \mathrm{~m}\) at the instant when \(Q\) starts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 484, 151, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 484, 319, 502]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 484, 920, 502]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 515, 153, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 700, 533]]<|/det|>
Find the distance between \(P\) and \(Q\) when \(Q\)'s speed reaches \(4 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 514, 920, 533]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 546, 153, 564]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 545, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
Sketch a single diagram showing the displacement-time graphs for both \(P\) and \(Q\), with values shown on the \(t\)-axis at which the speed of either particle changes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 560, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 743, 715, 762]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Questions 5, 6 and 7 are printed on the next page.]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[363, 84, 668, 298]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 317, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
A small block of mass \(1.25\mathrm{kg}\) is on a horizontal surface. Three horizontal forces, with magnitudes and directions as shown in the diagram, are applied to the block. The angle \(\theta\) is such that \(\cos \theta = 0.28\) and \(\sin \theta = 0.96\). A horizontal frictional force also acts on the block, and the block is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 380, 151, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 380, 920, 398]]<|/det|>
Show that the magnitude of the frictional force is \(7.5 \mathrm{N}\) and state the direction of this force. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 410, 151, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 410, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
Given that the block is in limiting equilibrium, find the coefficient of friction between the block and the surface. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 456, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
The force of magnitude \(6.1 \mathrm{N}\) is now replaced by a force of magnitude \(8.6 \mathrm{N}\) acting in the same direction, and the block begins to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 502, 149, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 502, 680, 520]]<|/det|>
Find the magnitude and direction of the acceleration of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 502, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 548, 92, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 546, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
A lorry of mass \(15 000\mathrm{kg}\) climbs a hill of length \(500\mathrm{m}\) at a constant speed. The hill is inclined at \(2.5^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The resistance to the lorry's motion is constant and equal to \(800\mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 593, 151, 611]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 593, 539, 611]]<|/det|>
Find the work done by the lorry's driving force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 593, 920, 611]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 623, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
On its return journey the lorry reaches the top of the hill with speed \(20 \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) and continues down the hill with a constant driving force of \(2000 \mathrm{N}\). The resistance to the lorry's motion is again constant and equal to \(800 \mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 686, 153, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 686, 677, 704]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of the lorry when it reaches the bottom of the hill.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 686, 920, 704]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 730, 94, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 730, 920, 765]]<|/det|>
A particle travels in a straight line from \(A\) to \(B\) in \(20 \mathrm{s}\). Its acceleration \(t\) seconds after leaving \(A\) is \(a \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 2}\), where \(a = \frac{3}{160} t^2 - \frac{1}{800} t^3\). It is given that the particle comes to rest at \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 780, 153, 797]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 780, 549, 797]]<|/det|>
Show that the initial speed of the particle is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 780, 920, 797]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 810, 153, 828]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 810, 484, 828]]<|/det|>
Find the maximum speed of the particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 810, 920, 828]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 841, 281, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 841, 332, 858]]<|/det|>
Find the distance \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 841, 920, 860]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 875, 920, 911]]<|/det|>
